title: Greta gets it wrong
text:
It is tempting to dismiss the histrionics of Greta Thunberg at the United Nations, and the indulgence of her by world leaders, as some modern Joan of Arc syndrome. That would be wrong. Climate change is a planetary problem and prompt action is needed. But it is not, as Ms Thunberg furiously claims, “business as usual” among her elders. Direct investment in green technology is growing very rapidly and becoming more effective as its cost falls. At recent rates of growth it should reach the US$800 billion in annual investment that McKinsey says will be needed before 2030. And there is not a single industry that isn’t going through a costly transition as it adapts to a low-carbon future.

The strongest signals to do all this are now coming from markets. As exclusively reported in The Australian Financial Review today, it is the former Socialist politician Antonio Guterres, the UN Secretary-General, who says that it’s private capital, not government, that is stepping up to “the economy of the future”. And it is Atlassian’s Mike Cannon-Brookes who is talking of exporting a new generation of Australian energy to Asia from giant solar farms. But destroying prosperity to hit the accelerated carbon targets that youthful demonstrators want is hardly a cure. What a teen from wealthy Sweden denounces as “fairytales of eternal economic growth” is the ladder out of poverty for millions in emerging economies, for whom access to reliable electricity is an essential step. Climate change is important, but young zealots who lack perspective are not the people who will fix it.
description: What a teen from wealthy Sweden denounces as “fairy tales of eternal economic growth” is the ladder out of poverty for millions.
